objectives: Tell and ask the time in Spanish
Name the days of the week and months

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Paciente
dialogue_blocks.text: Disculpe, ¿a qué hora abre la clínica?
dialogue_blocks.translation: Excuse me, what time does the clinic open?
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [disˈkulpe ‖ a ke ˈoɾa ˈaβɾe la ˈklinika]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Recepcionista
dialogue_blocks.text: Abrimos a las ocho de la mañana.
dialogue_blocks.translation: We open at eight in the morning.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [aˈβɾimos a las ˈotʃo ðe la maˈɲana]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Paciente
dialogue_blocks.translation: And which days are you open?

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Recepcionista
dialogue_blocks.text: De lunes a viernes. Los sábados, solo por la mañana.
dialogue_blocks.translation: Monday through Friday. Saturdays, mornings only.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [de ˈlunes a ˈβjeɾnes ‖ los ˈsaβaðos ˈsolo poɾ la maˈɲana]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Paciente
dialogue_blocks.text: ¿Puedo hacer una cita para el martes?
dialogue_blocks.translation: Can I make an appointment for Tuesday?
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [ˈpweðo aˈseɾ ˈuna ˈsita ˈpaɾa el ˈmaɾtes]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Recepcionista
dialogue_blocks.text: Sí, ¿a las diez y media le parece bien?
dialogue_blocks.translation: Yes, does ten thirty work for you?
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [ˈsi ‖ a las ˈdjes i ˈmeðja le paˈɾese ˈβjen]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Paciente
dialogue_blocks.text: Perfecto. El martes a las diez y media.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [peɾˈfekto ‖ el ˈmaɾtes a las ˈdjes i ˈmeðja]

srs_flashcards.front: Es la una / Son las dos
srs_flashcards.back: It's one o'clock / It's two o'clock

srs_flashcards.front: y media / y cuarto / menos cuarto
srs_flashcards.back: half past / quarter past / quarter to

exercises.question: How do you say 'It's half past two'?

feedback.correct: ¡Correcto! 'Son las dos y media' — 'son las' for all hours except 1.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: 'Son las [hour] y media' for half past. Only 'Es la una' for 1 o'clock.

speaking_rubric.title: Haz una cita (Make an appointment)
speaking_rubric.scenario: Call a doctor's office and schedule an appointment for next Thursday at 4pm.
speaking_rubric.prompt: Pide una cita para el jueves a las cuatro de la tarde.

scoring_criteria.description: Day, time and request all present

sample_response.text: Buenos días. ¿Puedo hacer una cita para el jueves a las cuatro de la tarde?
sample_response.ipa: [ˈbwenos ˈðias ‖ ˈpweðo aˈseɾ ˈuna ˈsita ˈpaɾa el ˈxweβes a las ˈkwatɾo ðe la ˈtaɾðe]

cultural_notes.formality: In Mexico, punctuality varies by context — business meetings are expected to start on time, but social events often start 30–60 min late ('la hora mexicana'). Appointments at clinics and offices are taken seriously.
cultural_notes.gestures: When referencing time, Mexicans often tap their wrist or point to where a watch would be even if not wearing one.
cultural_notes.regional_variations: In Mexico, the 12-hour clock is standard in conversation. '24:00' format is used on official schedules and transport timetables.
